natural solution: When using the distributive property for the first time, we add the product of $2p^2 - 1$ and $3p^2$ to the product of $2p^2 - 1$ and $4$: \begin{align} (2p^2 - 1)(3p^2 + 4) &= (2p^2 - 1) \cdot (3p^2) + (2p^2 - 1) \cdot 4
\end{align}We use the distributive property again and combine like terms: \begin{align} (3p^2)(2p^2 - 1) + 4(2p^2 - 1) &= 6p^4 - 3p^2 + 8p^2 - 4\\ &= \boxed{6p^4 + 5p^2 - 4} \end{align}

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> p. P p = 2 * p powr 2 - 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> p. Q p = 3 * p powr 2 + 4"
and h2 : "\<forall> p. R p = P p * Q p"
shows  "R p = 6 * p powr 4 + 5 * p powr 2 - 4"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Expand the product ${(2p^2 - 1)(3p^2 + 4)}$. The final Answer is 6p^4 + 5p^2 - 4
 ### Proof
 When using the distributive property for the first time, we add the product of $2p^2 - 1$ and $3p^2$ to the product of $2p^2 - 1$ and $4$: \begin{align} (2p^2 - 1)(3p^2 + 4) &= (2p^2 - 1) \cdot (3p^2) + (2p^2 - 1) \cdot 4
 \end{align}We use the distributive property again and combine like terms: \begin{align} (3p^2)(2p^2 - 1) + 4(2p^2 - 1) &= 6p^4 - 3p^2 + 8p^2 - 4\\ &= \boxed{6p^4 + 5p^2 - 4} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> p. P p = 2 * p powr 2 - 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> p. Q p = 3 * p powr 2 + 4"
and h2 : "\<forall> p. R p = P p * Q p"
shows  "R p = 6 * p powr 4 + 5 * p powr 2 - 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given that $P(p) = 2p^2 - 1$, $Q(p) = 3p^2 + 4$, and $R(p) = P(p) \cdot Q(p)$, find an expression for $R(p)$. The final answer is $R(p) = 6p^4 + 5p^2 - 4$.
